text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 1

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: MRS. D.A. MOORHOUSE
Address: A.N.E.R.O.I.B.I.SASK.
Birthplace: HASTINGS COUNTY, ONT.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1911 (my mother did)
Where did you set up housekeeping? BUFFALO HORN, SASK.
Where had you been living before that? BANGOR, ONT.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 6-8 (my mother)
How far was it to your nearest store? 7.5 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Every time in summer, not in winter.
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
flour, tea, sugar, salt, pepper, syrup, dried apples, oatmeal, prunes.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Robin Hood or King Ross
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs. and about 8 sacks at a time
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $3.00
How much did you use graham flour? None
Whole wheat flour? None
Was flour milled locally? No How far away? 7.5 miles What year? 1911
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $1.00
What other grain products did you use? None
Cornmeal? None Whole Wheat? None Farina? None
Other? None
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Sometimes
How did you grind it? With coffee grinder
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

Name: MRS. D.A. MOORHOUSE

Address: AMERSFOORT, ONT.

Birthplace: HASTINGS COUNTY, ONT.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1911 (my mother)

Where did you set up housekeeping? BEEFALO, HARBOR, SASK.

Where had you been living before that? BAYCROFT, ONT.

For how many people did you prepare meals? 6-8

How far was it to your nearest store? 7.5 miles

How often could a visit be made to the store? Weekly

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?

Flour, sugar, salt, pepper, dried apples, oatmeal, prunes.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Robin Hood or

In what quantities did you buy it? 1 lb. at a time, about 8-10 lbs.

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $3.40

How much did you use graham flour? 1/2 lb.

Whole wheat flour? 1 lb.

Was flour milled locally? No

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $1.00

What other grain products did you use?

Cornmeal? J.O. Miller

Other? None

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No

How did you grind it? With a coffee grinder
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 100 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $7.50

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Regal or Community White

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 1 lb.

At what price? $1.00

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? We always had our own cows brought out.

Butter? 25¢

Eggs? 25¢

What was the price of butter? 25¢

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes

Did you make butter? Yes

Cheese? No

What kind of cheese? Cottage cheese

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Pork we brought in at 2 pigs and a barrel of pork.

How did you get fresh meat? No except when we butchered.

How often did you get fresh meat? When we butchered.

How did you preserve meat? Yes, just rubbed on lots of salt.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes

If so what year was it organized? 1925

Did you use game? No

For how long? 1925

What part did fish play in the family diet? We went to Eaton's in winter for lots of herring, salted.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Salted

Kinds? Herring once in a while a can of salmon.
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 100 lbs. $7.50

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $2.50

What brand of Golden corn syrup did you use? Ralston

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 1 lb.

At what price? $1.00

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? From the farm.

What was the price of butter? $2.50

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes

Did you make butter? Yes

What kind of cheese? Butter cheese

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Pork, beef, mutton

How did you get fresh meat? From the farm

How often did you get fresh meat? Weekly

How did you preserve meat? Salted

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes

If so what year was it organized? 1925

Did you use games? Yes

For how long? Until 1925

What part did fish play in the family diet? Used for salted

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Cured

Was the fish whole or cut up? Whole

Kind of fish? Salmon
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Green tea. At what price? $2.50.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Coffee beans. How many bought? 10 lbs. Price? $2.50. What other beverages were used?

Was formally served black tea (Red Rose).

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? $4.00.

Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes.

If not, where from? 

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:

Potatoes 1911, Cabbage 1912, Carrots 1912, Onions 1911.

Turnips 1913, Beets 1913.

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? 

What weight? 20 lbs. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? 

What was the price of prunes? 

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others) Yes, all of them, but mostly apples.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? We brought home dried apples with us.

Peas? Yes, corn? Beans? Saskatoons? Other foods? 

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? About 1914.

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Everything except mushrooms.

To what extent? I have about 500 qts each year.

Did you make your own vinegar? Only in containers.
6. **REVENUES**

   What kind of tea did you buy?  
   At what price?  
   What kind of coffee did you buy?  
   (beans or ground)  
   At what price?  
   What other beverages were used?

7. **VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS**

   What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?  
   How much?  
   Could you get potatoes at the store?  
   If not, where from?  
   What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of?  
   Potatoes  
   Cabbage  
   Carrots  
   Onions  
   Turnips  
   Beets

   In what quantities did you buy white navy beans?  
   How did you buy prunes?  
   (in bulk or by the box?)  
   What weight?  
   How did the grocer handle prunes?  
   (by box?)  
   What was the price of prunes?  
   What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days?  
   (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)

8. **PRESERVING**

   In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying?  
   What year did you first preserve fruit?  
   What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning?  
   What year did you first preserve meat by canning?  
   Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying?  
   To what extent?  
   Did you make your own vinegar?
9. PLEASE FILL IN THE FOLLOWING TO THE BEST OF YOUR MEMORY:

| FOOD                  | Year you first remember seeing it in the store | How was it sold? - In bulk, 10 lb sack, can, etc. | Amt. you usually bought at one time | Price of this amount |
|-----------------------|-----------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------|---------------------|
| Soda biscuits         |                                               |                                                  |                                   |                     |
| Macaroni              | about 1920                                     |                                                  |                                   |                     |
| Graham flour          | about 1920                                     |                                                  |                                   |                     |
| Brown sugar           | we used it all the time in Ont., never saw white sugar |                                                  |                                   |                     |
| Molasses              | we had it in Ont., only a can at a time        |                                                  |                                   |                     |
| Table salt            | 1920                                           |                                                  |                                   |                     |
| Common salt           | in Ontario, we bought 25 lb bags                |                                                  |                                   |                     |
| Lily white syrup      | 1912                                           |                                                  |                                   |                     |
| Toilet soap           | 1912 only baby used it, we used Royal Crown bars |                                                  |                                   |                     |
| Baking powder         | 1911                                           |                                                  |                                   |                     |
| Baking soda           | in Ontario                                     |                                                  |                                   |                     |
| Dried peas            | we dried our own                               |                                                  |                                   |                     |
| Dried corn            |                                               | gal.                                              | 40¢ each                         |                     |
| Vinegar               | 1911                                           |                                                  |                                   |                     |
| Raisins - seeded      | in Ontario                                     | 20 lb                                             |                                   |                     |
| - seedless            | about 1916                                     |                                                  |                                   |                     |
| Rice                  | in Ontario                                     | 10 lb                                             | 90¢                              |                     |
| Currants              |                                                | 10 lb                                             | 1.00                             |                     |
| Store jam - kinds     | we didn't use much before 1919                 |                                                  |                                   |                     |
| Cheese (Cheddar or store cheese) | 1912 but we never had much, liked it, but couldn't afford it | | | |
| Vanilla               | in Ontario                                     | small bottle                                      |                                   | 25¢                 |

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal Yeast Cakes

Did you make yeast for your own use? Sometimes

Using starter? Yes

Using hops? No

Salt rising? No

Did you buy baking powder? Yes

Baking soda? Yes

Cream of tartar? Yes

Did you make your own baking powder? No

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? ____________________________
Did you make yeast for your own use? _______________________
Using hops? ________________________________________________
Did you buy baking powder? ________________________________
Cream of tartar? _________________________________________
Did you make your own baking powder? _____________________
11. PLEASE FILL IN THE FOLLOWING TO THE BEST OF YOUR MEMORY:

| FOOD                        | Earliest date it appeared on the market | Approximate price at the time | How did it differ from the same product today? |
|-----------------------------|----------------------------------------|------------------------------|------------------------------------------------|
| Canned salmon               | 1911                                   | 25¢                          | not much                                      |
| Canned sardines             | 1928                                   |                              | mother wouldn't eat them because they had their insides in |
| Other canned fish that appeared early - give names |                              |                              | no other one didn't go in for canned goods |
| Apples - fresh              |                                        | $1.00 box about 10 lbs        | none                                          |
| - dried                     | 1911                                   |                              | 1.00 box about 10 lbs before about 1925       |
| Lettuce                     | we never saw it in stores before about 1920 |                              |                                               |
| Tomatoes - fresh            |                                        | 3¢ each                      | none                                          |
| - canned                    | 1912                                   |                              |                                               |
| Bananas                     | 1917                                   |                              |                                               |
| Lemons                      | 1917                                   |                              |                                               |
| Oranges                     | 1917                                   |                              |                                               |
| Cornflakes                  | 1914                                   |                              |                                               |
| Other prepared breakfast cereals - give names | about 1920 shredded wheat, puffed wheat & rice |                              |                                               |
| Pearl tapioca               | 1920                                   |                              | Cent bought mostly                            |
| Minute tapioca              | 1925                                   | by 25¢ worth for sago         |                                               |
| Sago                        | 1920                                   |                              | always had stones in                           |
| Dates                       | 1922                                   |                              |                                               |
| Walnuts                     | 1918                                   | 10¢ package enough for 1 cake |                                               |
| Icing sugar                 |                                         |                              |                                               |

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) Slough water until mother got typhoid. Then from well.

How far was this water from your home? 3/4 mile

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) barrel

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We dug our own well in spring of 1912 Mr. E. Cooper helped dad.

| FOOD | Earliest date it appeared on the market | Approximate price at the time | How did it differ from the same product today? |
|------|----------------------------------------|-----------------------------|-----------------------------------------------|

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout)

How far was this water from your home?

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank)

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping.

We dug our own well in spring of 1912

Mrs. E. Cooper helped dad.
I remember the first time we saw Mrs. Condie. She called one evening, said she was looking for cows, saw our light the night before. She told mother about burning cow chips (manure). Mother was quite baffled because she had no wood to burn. And she told us a lot of things to help out. We had never eaten much oatmeal before, and Mrs. Condie told how to buy in quantity and the cheapest ways to eat on the prairie. She was a wonderful pioneer and about mother's age, and had 3 children who got to be our constant companions. Mrs. Condie was the first woman in the whole township. It took mother quite some time to get used to the fuel. She was sure she could taste it in the food.
I remember the first time we saw Miss Condie, she called one evening. Said she was looking for someone who knew about running cow ships (mormon) windmills over quite hilly because she had no room to burn. And she told us a lot of things to help out. We had never eaten much oatmeal before, and Miss Condie told how to buy in quantity and the cheapest ways to lay on the prairie. She was a wonderful pioneer and about mother age and had 3 children who got to be our Companions. Miss Condie was the first woman in the whole township. It took months quite some time to get used to the fuel. She was sure she could taste it in the food.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? If you made your own, did you use soap? What kind(s) of laundry soap did the grocer handle?

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Mention any changes in the way of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Mention any changes in the way of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates)

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade)

What year was it purchased? (Price?)

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade)

got a couple big gray granite pots for cooking & thank you

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

When did you first see enamel ware? (About 1914)

Aluminum? (1924)

The neighbors loaned me other dishes, cutlery, plates, cups, saucers, a bowl for feeding the chickens
13. SOAP
Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? If you made your own, did you use soap flakes, powdered soap, or liquid soap?

What kind of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Regular, detergent, or other?

14. FUEL
What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood, coal, oil, gas, or electricity?

Where did you get your fuel? From a nearby source, delivered by truck, or purchased at a store?

Mention any changes in the use of fuel which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

An early day had to go from candles to kerosene lamps, then to electric lights, and finally to gas or electricity.

A later day had to go from wood to coal, then to gas or electricity.

Now we use hard coal today.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS
For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates)

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made? A little homemade stove.

What year was it purchased? 1917

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade)

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

When did you first see enamel ware? About 1914

Aluminum? 1924

The neighbors loaned each other dishes, cutlery, pots, pans, and other household items.
17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner, and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: oatmeal over heated potatoes, cold boiled pork, tea.

Supper: In the winter, browned butter, syrup, etc.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? 1911.

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Mother always had a stuffed chicken and all the good things she could find, a Christmas cake, and we all had (not our stockings) but our lots filled with something to wear, maybe a shiny nipple (or these dad polished) other folks didn't have Christmas.

No Santa, Jim sure we were lucky.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Mother always had a wonderful garden. She always kept a few pigs. But I remember we didn't have money for flour once. I was coming home from school to find 50¢ a line was tilting up the old Canal and found 40¢ in change and somehow managed to get enough for the flour. It was 1914 in Summer. That was the advent of being...
17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with the ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: oatmeal, oven heated potatoes, cold boiled eggs, tea.

Supper: 2nd course, bread or rice pudding.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? 1911.

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Mother always had a stuffed chicken and all the good things she could find. A Christmas cake and we all had (not our stockings) but our lots filled with something to wear, maybe a shiny nickel (or these dad polished it), the fell back into obscure Christmas no Santa, I'm sure we were lucky.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Mother always had a wonderful garden. She always kept carrots a plug. But if memories fail me, there was money for flour once. I was coming home from school, I found 50¢. A line was tidying up herself. Carol a friend of ours in charge and somehow managed to get enough for the flour. It was 1914 in Summer. That was the advent of being remembered being.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? Give as many details and dates as possible.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed.)

I remember the barrel of cranberries and the can of corn in his store in 1917. I think my mother added a can of corn to our sample. There were no names for all the goods, so we tried to keep a straight face, finally we all burst out laughing, and so did the storekeeper.

Customers were always smiling or something, everything was fingered or handled & nothing remained.

Cats or dogs weren't always barred.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? Give as many details and dates as possible.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed.)

I remember the barrel of cranberries and the Cowan in his store in 1917. The Cowan was always friendly and we always laughed when he did the store paperwork.
The bachelor neighbors bought eggs, butter, bread from mother. Even chickens in springtime at $1.00 each. We found them all very honest. No one locked the door, and one time we were away, when we returned a bachelor had went down cellar & helped himself and left the money there.

An old German neighbor in Ontario had a big box made on legs, put in a whole 100 lbs of flour and set her bread yeast in the nest in the middle to keep it warm. Mother thought it was a grand idea, so dad made her one. The yeast never chilled. But the box had a flat lid on top, and one day my sister Lenna & her best bear were sitting on it about midnight she started to get off, and over it went, spreading mother's bread dough & flour all over.

A bachelor George Epps kept his bread yeast in a syrup pail in his bed to keep it warm & in the night he heard: POP! off flew the lid and the yeast went all over his bed.
The bachelor bought eggs.

Butter, bread from nothing, even chickens in spring time at $1.00 each. We found them all very honest. No one locked the door, and one time we were away when we returned a bachelor had moved down cellar & helped himself and kept the money there.

An old German neighbor in Ontario put in a whole lot of flour and kept it warm. We had a big box made out of bread yeast in the middle to keep it warm, so that mother thought it was a grand idea, and one day my sister Emma & I went there were dead mopes for one. The yeast was chilled.

But the box held a flat lid on top, and one day my sister Emma & I went there were dead mopes for one. The yeast was chilled.

A bachelor bought eggs kept his bread in a syrup tail in his bed to keep it warm, and the next morning the yeast went off over his bed.
